content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections, and "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser without a US place of business. A private fund adviser is an investment adviser with no US place of business, fewer than 15 clients in the US, and assets under management for US clients of less than $25,000,000. The Commission may deem appropriate in the public interest or for investor protection. The entity should not hold itself out as an investment adviser in the US or act as one for registered investment companies. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, the amendments include provisions for small business investment companies and entities approved by the Small Business Administration. Entities eligible for exceptions under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 include those approved by the Small Business Administration for a license or those with pending license applications related to licensed small business investment companies. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to authorize the Commission to require registered investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds advised by them in the public interest. The Commission can require investment advisers to maintain records and reports on private funds for public interest and investor protection. The Commission can share this information with the Federal Reserve and other entities responsible for systemic risk assessment. Investment advisers must maintain records and reports on private funds they advise, which will be considered the adviser's own records. These records must include the amount of assets under management for each private fund. The subsection requires investment advisers to report on private funds, including assets under management, leverage usage, counterparty credit risk, trading positions, practices, and additional information deemed necessary by the Commission and the Federal Reserve. The Commission may require private fund advisers to report additional information as deemed necessary for the public interest and systemic risk assessment, with different reporting requirements based on the types or sizes of private funds advised. Private fund advisers must adhere to different reporting requirements based on the types or sizes of private funds they advise. They are also mandated to maintain records of these funds for a specified period as deemed necessary by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Private fund advisers registered under this Act must allow the Commission to conduct periodic and special examinations of all records of the private fund. The adviser is also required to make these records available as needed. The Investment adviser registered under this Act must provide the Commission with copies of records upon request. The Commission will share information with the Federal Reserve Board and other entities with systemic risk responsibility. The Commission will provide copies of reports, documents, records, and information filed by investment advisers to the Federal Reserve Board or other entities for assessing systemic risk of private funds. The information obtained will be kept confidential as per Commission's confidentiality guidelines. The subsection requires confidentiality consistent with Commission guidelines. Investment advisers must provide reports, records, and documents to certain parties for the public interest, investor protection, and systemic risk assessment. The Commission may prescribe regulations for the protection of investors and systemic risk assessment. Reports filed with the Commission under this subsection are confidential and not subject to disclosure, except to Congress or other federal agencies. The Commission may prescribe regulations for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. Reports filed with the Commission are confidential and not disclosed, except to Congress, federal agencies, or in compliance with court orders. SEC. 5 amends the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 by removing a disclosure provision. SEC. 6 exempts and requires reporting by venture capital fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption for venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements, with the Commission defining the term 'venture capital fund' and requiring advisers to maintain records and provide necessary reports. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt venture capital fund advisers from registration requirements. Advisers must define 'venture capital fund' and provide necessary reports to the Commission. SEC. 7. EXEMPTION OF AND REPORTING BY CERTAIN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. Advisers exempted must maintain reporting requirements. The Commission exempts investment advisers of private funds with assets under $150,000,000 from registration. Advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. Regulations for mid-sized private fund advisers consider fund size, governance, and investment strategy. The Commission considers the size, governance, and investment strategy of mid-sized private funds to determine systemic risk and establish registration and examination procedures for their advisers. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make, amend, and rescind rules and regulations necessary for its functions, including defining technical terms and classifying persons and matters based on size. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on various factors and prescribe different requirements for different classes. It can also assign different meanings to terms, excluding the term 'client' for investors. The Commission has the authority to classify persons and matters within its jurisdiction based on various factors and prescribe different requirements for different classes. It can also assign different meanings to terms, excluding the term 'client' for investors. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission shall consult with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System within 12 months after the date of enactment of the title. The Commission, in consultation with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, will establish rules for reports to be filed with the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to assess the annual costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements under the Act. A report containing the findings will be submitted to Congress within 2 years. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period from the enactment date. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the effective date. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. Section 205(e) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require the Commission to adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
